title: Cardinal Dolan, religious leaders push to shutter Rikers Island
text:
“Rikers has got to go. It is contrary to the Bible’s teaching to treat folks like this so harshly," said Cardinal Timothy Dolan. | Drew Angerer/Getty Images Cardinal Dolan, religious leaders push to shutter Rikers Island

Cardinal Timothy Dolan and other religious leaders gave their blessing Thursday to the push to shut down Rikers Island.

The head of the Catholic Archdiocese of New York, standing with a group of rabbis and ministers outside Manhattan Supreme Court, called it a moral imperative to close the violence-plagued jail complex.

Story Continued Below

“Rikers has got to go. It is contrary to the Bible’s teaching to treat folks like this so harshly. It’s contrary to our American values of fairness and hope and justice. And you know what? It’s just plain contrary to common sense,” Dolan said.

“In the name of our good God, let’s tear down this place.”

The city is pursuing a plan to close Rikers and replace it with four smaller jails, a blueprint which has become embroiled in controversy as it wends its way through the City Council. The proposal calls for a jail in each borough except for Staten Island, which proponents say would be better built, allow prisoners to maintain connections to their families and neighborhoods and speed up their processing by putting them closer to courts.

But neighborhood opponents have objected to the placement of the jails, saying the planned buildings are too big and some of the locations inappropriate. Activists on the left have attacked the plans on the grounds that the city should not be opening new jails at all.

New statistics just revealed in the Mayor’s Management Report showed that violence has surged at the island jail complex — with attacks between inmates up 25 percent since 2018, and assaults against staff up more than a third.

Use of force by guards against prisoners has also jumped nearly percent.

Judge Jonathan Lippman, the former chief judge of the New York state court system who led a commission that recommended closing Rikers, said the spike in violence makes it “so much more urgent” to get the closure plan done quickly.

“Rikers is a stain on the soul of New York City. ... Every day, human beings are suffering," he said. “If we don’t do it now, it will be another 30 years.”

A federal investigation found the jail was a dysfunctional institution plagued by a deep-seated culture of violence.

Dolan said he has visited many jails and prisons, and while “none of them are Park Avenue condos,” Rikers has stood out for its structural defects.

“What strikes me immediately when I go to Rikers is the dreariness of it, the isolation of it, the darkness of it,” he said.
